bestBHT.bht: Moses avenged and defended the Hebrew who was suffering from the Egyptian's oppression by striking him. This act of defending the oppressed and retaliating for the wrong done is commendable, revealing Moses' heroic courage bestowed upon him by the Holy Spirit. The incident of burying the Egyptian in the sand, whether metaphorical or literal, shows the measures Moses took to conceal the body. This act illustrates Moses' role as the future deliverer of the Israelites, as he courageously stood up against injustice.

Henry Alford: 24.] the Egyptian, from the history being so universally known, that the agent of the wrong would be readily supplied.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: and smote the Egyptian—going farther in the heat of his
Albert Barnes: Suffer wrong - The wrong or injury was, that the Egyptian was smiting the Hebrew, Exodus 2:11-12.
Smote the Egyptian - He slew him, and buried him in the sand,
Marvin Vincent: The word means originally to ward off from one's self, with a collateral notion of requital or revenge.
John Calvin: It is a godly deed, and praiseworthy, for a man to set himself against the wicked, to defend the good against the injuries of the wicked, to bridle their violence.
But this heroical courage and nobleness of heart was a work of the Holy Ghost; because God doth mightily show forth his power in those whom he appointeth unto great matters.

In sum, Stephen meaneth that Moses was even then offered to be the minister of deliverance when the day was at hand, according to the covenant made with Abraham, yet did the people hope for nothing less.
Philip Schaff: Suffer wrong. That is, injured by blows, as in Exodus 2:11.
And smote the Egyptian. He struck the Egyptian who did the wrong so as to kill him.
‘The Egyptian,’ simply without any previous allusion, because the story was so well known.
Archibald T. Robertson: Avenged. This idiom occurs in Luke 18:7 with εκδικησιν.
Him that was oppressed. The man was on the point of being overcome.
John Gill: Moses went out to the camp of the Israelites, and saw an Egyptian smite one of the sons of Kohath, who was of his brethren of the tribe of Levi.

and he hid him in the sand", as it is in Exodus 2:12 and which the Jews understand not literally of any sand pit, into which he might cast him, and cover him; or of the sand of the sea, near which he was, and which does not appear; but mystically of the people of Israel, comparable to the sand of the sea, among whom he hid him.
Moses slew the Egyptian with the ineffable name of God, and hid him among the children of Israel, who are like to sand.
John Wesley: Seeing one wronged — Probably by one of the task masters.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Acts 7:24, it is mentioned that Moses took matters into his own hands and defended the Hebrew who was being oppressed by smiting the Egyptian. This act of defending the oppressed and avenging the wrong is commendable. Moses, in the heat of his anger, went beyond what he had initially intended, symbolizing the heroism and courage bestowed upon him by the Holy Spirit. It is worth noting that this incident was well-known and widely recognized. Moses' action of burying the Egyptian in the sand, though understood metaphorically by some as hiding him among the vast number of the Israelite people, can also be seen as a physical act to conceal the body. Ultimately, Moses' act of defending the oppressed foreshadows his future role as the deliverer of the Israelites.

Moses avenged and defended the Hebrew who was suffering from the Egyptian's oppression by striking him. This act of defending the oppressed and retaliating for the wrong done is commendable, revealing Moses' heroic courage bestowed upon him by the Holy Spirit. The incident of burying the Egyptian in the sand, whether metaphorical or literal, shows the measures Moses took to conceal the body. This act illustrates Moses' role as the future deliverer of the Israelites, as he courageously stood up against injustice.

Moses, driven by his indignation, sought justice by defending and avenging the Hebrew who was oppressed, delivering blows to the Egyptian. This act of standing up against the wicked and protecting the righteous displays Moses' noble heart and heroism, instilled by the Holy Spirit. The incident, widely known, involved Moses burying the Egyptian, either literally or metaphorically within the Israelite community. This courageous act foreshadows Moses' future role as the deliverer, appointed by God, and sets the stage for the fulfillment of the covenant made with Abraham.

Moses, in defense of the Hebrew who was suffering from oppression, took action and struck the Egyptian, seeking to avenge the wrong that was done. This act of bravery and retaliation against injustice was empowered by the Holy Spirit, showcasing the divine power at work in those chosen for great tasks. By burying the Egyptian, whether literally or symbolically, Moses concealed the evidence of his actions. This courageous act foreshadows Moses' future role as the minister of deliverance according to God's covenant.

Moses, driven by his indignation, struck the Egyptian who was oppressing the Hebrew, seeking to avenge the wrong that had been done. This act of defending the oppressed and retaliating against injustice was a demonstration of Moses' heroism, granted through the Holy Spirit's power. The incident of burying the Egyptian, whether literally or symbolically, remains widely recognized. Moses' courageous action foreshadowed his future role as the deliverer appointed by God, as the people were yet unaware of the imminent hope placed on Moses.
